name: Fall Armyworm
symptoms: Chewed leaves, ragged holes, frass in whorls
solution: Pheromone traps for monitoring, collect/destroy egg masses and larvae, neem‑based sprays or azadirachtin

name: African Maize Stalk Borer (Busseola fusca)
symptoms: Small holes ('windows') in new leaves, yellowing leaf hearts, dead hearts, stem tunneling
solution: Push–pull intercrops (Desmodium + Napier grass), early planting, breaking stems postharvest, release parasitic wasps, neem or ash in whorl

name: Spotted Stem Borer (Chilo partellus)
symptoms: Pinholes and 'windows' in leaf whorls, elongated lesions, dead hearts, stem bore tunnels
solution: Intercrop, Trichogramma egg‑parasitoids, neem treatments, cultural sanitation, early detection and spray insecticides

name: Yellow Top Borer (Chilo infuscatellus)
symptoms: Small holes in leaves, shoot tips killed, dead hearts, frass in stems
solution: Remove and destroy affected plants, insecticide application at early instars, crop hygiene

name: African Sugarcane Borer (Eldana saccharina)
symptoms: Stem tunneling, brittle stalks, broken stems, frass deposits
solution: Intercropping, biological control with parasitic wasps, destroy crop residues, maintain plant health

name: Corn Aphid (Rhopalosiphum maidis)
symptoms: Yellowing and stunting, sticky honeydew, sooty mold, virus transmission (e.g. maize dwarf mosaic)
solution: Encourage predators (ladybugs, lacewings), use resistant varieties, apply insecticides (e.g. acetamiprid) if heavy

name: Shoot Bug / Peregrinus maidis
symptoms: Leaf yellowing, wilting, stem weakening, plant death, transmits MMV and MStV viruses
solution: Use vector‑resistant varieties, field sanitation, remove alternate hosts, control with insecticides, monitor early

name: Two‑spotted Spider Mite (Tetranychus urticae)
symptoms: Yellowish stippling on leaves, webbing under leaves, leaf drying and shriveling
solution: Introduce predatory mites and lady beetles, spray dicofol or wettable sulfur or chlorfenvinphos

name: Banks Grass Mite (Oligonychus pratensis)
symptoms: Leaf yellowing, stippling, webbing similar to two‑spotted mite, earlier season infestations
solution: Biological predators, early detection, chemical sprays like sulfur or chlorfenapyr

name: Aphids (general)
symptoms: Sap‑sucking causing mottling, stunting, sooty mold, viral disease spread
solution: Natural enemies (ladybirds, hover flies), seed treatment, resistant varieties, insecticides if severe

name: African Pink Stem Borer (Sesamia calamistis)
symptoms: Larvae bore stem; dead hearts, broken stem, tunnels in ear sheaths
solution: Pull and burn dead‑hearts, apply granules (e.g. carbofuran, carbaryl) in whorls at specific crop ages

name: Maize Bollworm (Helicoverpa armigera)
symptoms: Holes in whorl and ears, faecal granules near feeding, ear damage, open tips
solution: Spray spinosad, indoxacarb or thiodicarb upon egg-hatch, two timed applications, resistant varieties

name: Cutworms
symptoms: Seedlings cut off at ground level, wilting or missing plants
solution: Seed dressing, soil baiting, keep field weed‑free, rotate crops

name: Maize Weevil
symptoms: Storage pest: holes in kernels, weight and quality loss, larvae inside grain
solution: Proper storage (airtight containers), dust with spinosad or phosphine fumigation

name: Larger Grain Borer
symptoms: Grains eaten completely inside storage, tunnels throughout kernels
solution: Dry maize thoroughly before storage, use proper storage bins, treat with recommended dusts

name: Rodents (rats/mice)
symptoms: Gnawed cobs, eaten kernels, grain spoilage
solution: Use rat traps or poison, maintain hygiene around storage, encourage predators

name: Sorghum Shoot Fly
symptoms: Seedling dead‑heart: central shoot withers and dies within 1 month
solution: Early sowing, high seed rate, seed treatment (imidacloprid or thiamethoxam), intercropping, soil granules

name: Sorghum Stem Borer
symptoms: Ragged‑edged oblong holes in leaves, defoliation, stem borers later
solution: Deep ploughing, synchronized planting, pheromone traps, collect larvae, neem or cyantraniliprole seed treatment

name: Sorghum Midge (Stenodiplosis sorghicola)
symptoms: Chaffy (shrunken) grains, emergence holes, pupal cases visible on spikelets
solution: Synchronized planting, destroy residues, conserve parasitoids, plant tolerant varieties

name: Sorghum Earhead Bug (Calocoris angustatus)
symptoms: Grain sucking causing dusty black chaffy head‑tips, milky sap ooze
solution: Monitor earheads, encourage natural enemies, spray appropriate insecticide early

name: Brown Planthopper
symptoms: Plants yellow, wilt; hopper burn; stunted growth; transmits grassy stunt and ragged stunt viruses
solution: Use resistant rice varieties; maintain field hygiene; avoid over‑fertilization; apply approved insecticides only when thresholds reached

name: Rice Stem Borer
symptoms: Deadhearts in vegetative stage; whiteheads at grain‑fill; tunnels in stems
solution: Plant early; use pheromone traps; remove stubble; apply biological control (parasitoids)

name: Cassava Mosaic Virus (CMD)
symptoms: Mosaic leaf chlorosis; distortion; stunting; poor yields
solution: Use disease‑resistant varieties; rogue infected plants; plant virus‑free planting material

name: Cassava Brown Streak Disease (CBSD)
symptoms: Brown streaks on roots and stems; necrotic roots; above‑ground yellowing leaves
solution: Use tolerant varieties; remove and destroy infected plants; plant clean seed

name: Groundnut Leaf Miner
symptoms: Leaf mining trails; defoliation; reduced pod set
solution: Intercrop; timely planting; biological control where available

name: Bean Aphid
symptoms: Leaf curling; stunting; honeydew and sooty mold; virus transmission
solution: Encourage predators (ladybugs); use resistant varieties; spray neem or insecticide if heavy

name: Cowpea Pod Borer (Maruca vitrata)
symptoms: Larvae bore into buds and pods; malformed pods; yield loss
solution: Deploy pheromone traps; intercropping; timely spraying with biopesticides

name: Tobacco Thrips
symptoms: Silvery leaf stippling; distorted new leaves; flower bud deformation
solution: Use insect-proof nets; apply sticky traps; spray spinosad or neem

name: Tobacco Cutworm
symptoms: Seedlings cut at soil level; missing seedlings; chewed leaves
solution: Seed dressing; clean field; baits; early planting

name: Cotton Bollworm (Helicoverpa armigera)
symptoms: Holes in bolls and flowers; larval frass on blooms; premature boll opening
solution: Spray spinosad/indoxacarb; pheromone traps; use Bt‑cotton where permitted

name: Sunflower Rust (Puccinia helianthi)
symptoms: Orange pustules on leaf surface; leaf defoliation; reduced head size
solution: Use resistant hybrids; practice crop rotation; apply fungicide early

name: Tomato Leaf Miner (Tuta absoluta)
symptoms: Leaf mines; rolled leaves; fruit scarring; severe defoliation
solution: Use pheromone traps; biological control (Trichogramma); insect netting; early insecticide use

name: Tomato Fruit Worm (Helicoverpa armigera)
symptoms: Chewed fruit; discoloration; frass around entry holes
solution: Remove infected fruits; spray compatible insecticides or neem; use pheromone monitoring

name: African Bollworm
symptoms: Feeding holes on pods/flowers/leaves; larval frass
solution: Intercrop; trap cropping; insecticide timing on egg hatch

name: Okra Shoot Fly (Atherigona spp.)
symptoms: Central shoot killed; seedling dead hearts
solution: Seed treatment; early sowing; intercropping; field sanitation

name: Onion Thrips
symptoms: Silver streaks on leaves; curled leaf tips; bulb shrinkage
solution: Use reflective mulches; release predators; apply sticky traps; spray insecticides when needed

name: Cabbage Loopers
symptoms: Large semi-circular holes in leaves; frass on lower leaves; skeletonized foliage
solution: Handpick; encourage parasitic wasps; neem spray

name: Diamondback Moth
symptoms: Small holes between veins; webbing on underside; stunted heads
solution: Use row covers; apply Bt‑based bioinsecticides; release parasitoids

name: Bean Thrips
symptoms: Silvery speckling on leaves; leaf distortion; pod discoloration
solution: Encourage natural enemies; spray insecticidal soap or neem; field sanitation

name: Banana Weevil
symptoms: Exit holes in pseudostem; wilting; physical stalk breakage; reduced bunch weight
solution: Remove and destroy residues; use clean planting material; apply entomopathogenic nematodes or biopesticides
